title: How to Reset Your University Password
content:
Forgetting your university password can be frustrating, but resetting it is a straightforward process. There are two primary methods to reset your password depending on your situation.

Method 1: Self-Service Password Reset
If you have previously set up security questions or registered a personal email or phone number, you can use the self-service portal at passwords.university.edu. Click 'Forgot Password' and enter your university ID (typically your student or employee ID number). You will receive a verification code via your registered recovery method. Enter this code and create a new password that meets the university's password requirements: at least 12 characters, including uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.

Method 2: IT Help Desk Assistance
If you cannot access the self-service portal, visit the IT Help Desk in the Library Building, Room 102, or call (555) 123-4567 during business hours (Monday-Friday, 8 AM - 6 PM). You will need to present a valid university ID card for in-person visits. Remote verification requires answering security questions from your student or employee record.

Important Password Guidelines:
- Passwords expire every 180 days for security purposes
- You cannot reuse your last 10 passwords
- Avoid using personal information like birthdays or names
- Consider using a passphrase for better security and memorability

After resetting your password, remember to update it on all devices where you access university services, including your phone's email app and any saved browser passwords.
snippet: Learn how to reset your university password using the self-service portal or by contacting the IT Help Desk.

title: Setting Up Your University Email Account
content:
Your university email account is essential for receiving official communications, course updates, and collaborating with peers and faculty. This guide will help you set up access to your university email across various platforms.

Accessing Email via Web Browser
The easiest way to access your email is through the web portal at mail.university.edu. Log in using your university credentials (your NetID and password). The web interface provides full functionality including email, calendar, contacts, and OneDrive integration.

Setting Up Email on Mobile Devices
iPhone/iPad: Go to Settings > Mail > Accounts > Add Account > Microsoft Exchange. Enter your full university email address (netid@university.edu) and password. The server settings should auto-configure.

Android: Open the Gmail app or your preferred email client. Add a new account and select Exchange or Office 365. Enter your university email address and follow the prompts. You may need to enable device management when prompted.

Desktop Email Clients
For Outlook Desktop: Open Outlook and go to File > Add Account. Enter your university email and password. Outlook will automatically configure the connection settings.

For Apple Mail: Go to Mail > Add Account > Microsoft Exchange. Enter your email and password, then allow any requested permissions.

Email Storage and Quotas
Your mailbox has a 50 GB storage limit. When you reach 90% capacity, you will receive a warning notification. Consider archiving old emails or deleting unnecessary messages to maintain space.

Email Forwarding
You can set up email forwarding to a personal account, but we recommend checking your university email directly to ensure you receive time-sensitive communications. To set up forwarding, log into mail.university.edu, go to Settings > Mail > Forwarding, and enter your preferred address.
snippet: Step-by-step instructions for setting up your university email on web browsers, mobile devices, and desktop clients.

title: Troubleshooting Canvas LMS Login Issues
content:
Canvas is the university's Learning Management System (LMS) where you access course materials, submit assignments, and participate in discussions. If you're experiencing login problems, this guide will help you resolve common issues.

Accessing Canvas
Canvas is available at canvas.university.edu. You should log in using your university NetID and password (the same credentials you use for email and other university services).

Common Login Issues and Solutions

1. Invalid Credentials Error
If you receive an 'invalid username or password' message, first verify that you're using your NetID (not your student ID number or personal email). Try resetting your password at passwords.university.edu if you're unsure of your current password.

2. Account Not Found
New students may not have immediate Canvas access. Account provisioning typically occurs within 24-48 hours of enrollment confirmation. If you've been enrolled for more than 48 hours and still cannot access Canvas, contact the Registrar's Office to verify your enrollment status.

3. Courses Not Appearing
If you can log in but don't see your courses, check that your courses have been published by your instructors. Courses typically become visible 1-2 weeks before the semester starts. Also verify your enrollment through the Student Portal.

4. Browser Compatibility Issues
Canvas works best with Chrome, Firefox, or Safari (latest versions). If you're experiencing issues, try clearing your browser cache and cookies, or switch to a different browser. Disable browser extensions that might interfere with Canvas functionality.

5. Mobile App Issues
For the Canvas mobile app, ensure you're searching for 'University' when selecting your institution during setup. If the app isn't working, try uninstalling and reinstalling it, or use the mobile web browser as an alternative.

If problems persist after trying these solutions, contact the IT Help Desk or use the live chat feature at it.university.edu/support.
snippet: Solutions for common Canvas LMS login problems including invalid credentials, missing courses, and browser issues.

title: Connecting to Campus WiFi Networks
content:
The university provides several WiFi networks across campus to meet different needs. This guide explains how to connect to the appropriate network for your situation.

Available Networks

1. UniSecure (Recommended)
This is the primary network for students, faculty, and staff. It provides the fastest speeds and most secure connection.

2. UniGuest
A limited-access network for campus visitors. Requires accepting terms of service but no login credentials.

3. UniDevices
For IoT devices, gaming consoles, and smart devices that don't support enterprise authentication.

Connecting to UniSecure

Windows 10/11:
1. Click the WiFi icon in the system tray
2. Select 'UniSecure' from the list
3. Enter your university NetID and password when prompted
4. Click 'Connect' and accept any certificate prompts

macOS:
1. Click the WiFi icon in the menu bar
2. Select 'UniSecure'
3. Enter your NetID and password
4. When prompted about the certificate, click 'Continue' and enter your Mac password to trust it

iOS (iPhone/iPad):
1. Go to Settings > WiFi
2. Tap 'UniSecure'
3. Enter your NetID and password
4. Tap 'Trust' when prompted about the certificate

Android:
1. Go to Settings > Network & Internet > WiFi
2. Select 'UniSecure'
3. For EAP method, select 'PEAP'
4. Phase 2 authentication: 'MSCHAPV2'
5. Enter your NetID and password
6. For CA certificate, select 'Use system certificates' or 'Don't validate'

Troubleshooting Tips
- Forget the network and reconnect if experiencing issues
- Ensure your password is current (not recently changed)
- Check that your device isn't blocked due to security concerns
- Move closer to an access point if signal is weak

For device registration on UniDevices, visit wifi.university.edu/register.
snippet: Instructions for connecting to UniSecure and other campus WiFi networks on Windows, Mac, iOS, and Android devices.

title: VPN Setup for Off-Campus Access
content:
The university's Virtual Private Network (VPN) allows you to securely access campus resources from off-campus locations. This is required for accessing library databases, research systems, administrative applications, and other restricted resources.

When to Use VPN
- Accessing library databases and journals from home
- Connecting to departmental file shares
- Using administrative systems that require on-campus access
- Securing your connection on public WiFi networks
- Accessing research computing resources

Installing the VPN Client

The university uses Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client.

1. Visit vpn.university.edu from any web browser
2. Log in with your university NetID and password
3. Complete multi-factor authentication when prompted
4. Download the appropriate client for your operating system
5. Run the installer and follow the prompts

Connecting to VPN

1. Open Cisco AnyConnect from your applications
2. Enter 'vpn.university.edu' as the server address
3. Click 'Connect'
4. Enter your NetID and password
5. Complete MFA verification (push notification or code)
6. You'll see 'Connected' status when successful

VPN Connection Types
When connecting, you may be prompted to select a connection profile:
- Full Tunnel: Routes all internet traffic through VPN (use for sensitive work)
- Split Tunnel: Only routes university traffic through VPN (better performance for general use)

Troubleshooting
- If connection fails, verify your credentials are correct
- Ensure MFA is properly set up on your account
- Check that your antivirus isn't blocking the VPN client
- Try disconnecting and reconnecting if connection drops
- Contact IT Help Desk if you receive 'connection attempt failed' errors repeatedly

Note: VPN sessions timeout after 12 hours of inactivity. Simply reconnect when needed.
snippet: How to install and configure the university VPN for secure off-campus access to library resources and campus systems.

title: Downloading and Installing Microsoft Office 365
content:
All currently enrolled students, faculty, and staff are entitled to download and install Microsoft Office 365 on up to 5 personal computers and 5 mobile devices at no additional cost. This includes Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, OneNote, and other Microsoft applications.

Downloading Office 365

1. Visit office.com and click 'Sign In'
2. Enter your university email address (netid@university.edu)
3. You'll be redirected to the university login page
4. Enter your NetID and password, then complete MFA if prompted
5. Once logged in, click 'Install Office' in the top right corner
6. Select 'Office 365 apps' to download the full suite
7. Run the downloaded installer

Installation Notes
- The download is approximately 4 GB; ensure stable internet connection
- Installation takes 15-30 minutes depending on your internet speed
- Close all Office applications before installing
- You may need administrator rights on your computer

Activating Office
After installation, open any Office application (e.g., Word). Sign in with your university email when prompted. The software will automatically activate with your university license.

Mobile Installation
For iOS: Download individual Office apps from the App Store and sign in with your university email.
For Android: Download from Google Play Store and sign in with university credentials.

Important Information
- Your Office license remains active while you're enrolled or employed
- After leaving the university, you'll have a 30-day grace period before the license expires
- Files created with Office will remain accessible; only the editing features will be limited
- OneDrive cloud storage (5 TB) is included with your account

For installation issues, contact the IT Help Desk. Include your operating system version and any error messages received.
snippet: Free Microsoft Office 365 download and installation instructions for students and staff on computers and mobile devices.

title: Setting Up Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
content:
Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of security to your university account by requiring two forms of verification: your password and a second factor like your phone. MFA is required for all university accounts.

Setting Up MFA

1. Visit mfa.university.edu
2. Log in with your university NetID and password
3. Choose your preferred authentication method
4. Complete the setup wizard

Authentication Methods Available

1. Microsoft Authenticator App (Recommended)
- Download the free app on iOS or Android
- Scan the QR code displayed during setup
- Receive push notifications for quick approval
- Also generates time-based codes when offline

2. Phone Call
- Receive an automated call to your registered phone
- Press # to confirm your identity
- Works with any phone that can receive calls

3. SMS Text Message
- Receive a 6-digit code via text
- Enter the code when prompted
- Standard messaging rates may apply

4. Hardware Security Key (FIDO2)
- For users requiring highest security
- Requires compatible USB or NFC security key
- Contact IT Security team for provisioning

Managing Your MFA Settings
To add backup methods, change your default option, or update your phone number, visit mfa.university.edu and select 'Manage authentication methods.' We strongly recommend configuring at least two methods in case one is unavailable.

Troubleshooting MFA Issues
- Time sync issues: Ensure your phone's time is set automatically
- New phone: Use your backup method to log in, then register the new device
- Lost phone: Contact IT Help Desk for temporary bypass
- App not receiving notifications: Check that notifications are enabled and you have internet connectivity

Recovery Options
Keep your backup authentication methods current. If locked out without backup options, visit the IT Help Desk in person with valid ID for account recovery.
snippet: Guide to setting up and managing Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) using the Authenticator app, phone, or SMS.

title: Using Campus Printing Services
content:
The university provides convenient printing services across campus through UniPrint. This guide covers how to print from personal devices, lab computers, and how to manage your print allocation.

Print Allocation
All students receive a semesterly print allocation:
- Undergraduate students: $50 credit per semester
- Graduate students: $75 credit per semester
- Printing costs: $0.05 per B&W page, $0.25 per color page

Unused balances expire at the end of each semester. Additional funds can be added at the UniCard office.

Printing from Campus Computers
1. Send your document to print as normal (Ctrl+P or Cmd+P)
2. Select 'UniPrint' as your printer
3. Go to any UniPrint release station on campus
4. Tap your university ID card or log in with your NetID
5. Select the jobs you want to print and confirm

Printing from Personal Devices

Web Upload:
1. Visit print.university.edu
2. Log in with your university credentials
3. Upload your document (PDF recommended)
4. Select print options (color, double-sided, etc.)
5. Release at any UniPrint station

Mobile Printing:
1. Email your document to print@university.edu from your university email
2. Release at any UniPrint station within 24 hours

Printer Locations
UniPrint stations are located in:
- All campus libraries (open during library hours)
- Student Center (24/7 access with ID)
- Residence hall computer labs
- Academic building computer labs

Specialty Printing
For large format printing, poster printing, or binding services, visit the Print Shop in the Student Center basement. Professional staff can assist with projects and provide quotes for specialty jobs.

Troubleshooting
- Jobs expire after 24 hours if not released
- Check paper size matches your document
- Large files may take several minutes to process
- Report printer malfunctions using the QR code on each device
snippet: How to use UniPrint campus printing services, manage your print allocation, and print from personal devices.

title: Student Software Discounts and Free Downloads
content:
The university provides students, faculty, and staff with access to free and discounted software for academic use. Take advantage of these resources to save hundreds of dollars on essential applications.

Free Software for Students

Microsoft Office 365: Full suite including Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and 5TB OneDrive storage. Download from office.com using university credentials.

Adobe Creative Cloud: Selected programs may be available through department-specific licenses. Check with your academic department for access.

MATLAB: Free campus-wide license for all students. Download from mathworks.com/academia and verify with your university email.

Statistical Software (SPSS, SAS, R): Available through the Statistics Lab or for download at software.university.edu.

Antivirus Protection: Free Sophos antivirus for all university-owned and personal devices. Download from it.university.edu/antivirus.

Discounted Software

Visit software.university.edu to access the university software portal, which offers academic pricing on popular titles:
- Windows OS upgrades: $15-25
- Final Cut Pro: $199 (normally $299)
- Parallels Desktop: $49 (normally $99)
- Various specialized software at 50-90% off retail

Developer Resources
Students in computing fields can access:
- GitHub Student Developer Pack (free)
- JetBrains IDEs (free with .edu email)
- Azure for Students ($100 credit)
- AWS Educate (free tier access)

Eligibility and Verification
Most software requires verification of current enrollment. This is typically done by:
- Logging in with your university email
- Uploading proof of enrollment
- Automatic verification through university systems

Software Licensing Terms
Most academic licenses are for educational use only. Review individual license agreements for restrictions on commercial use. Licenses typically expire upon graduation or separation from the university.
snippet: Free and discounted software available to students including Microsoft Office, MATLAB, Adobe tools, and developer resources.

title: Reporting Security Incidents and Phishing
content:
Protecting university data and systems is everyone's responsibility. If you encounter a security threat or believe your account has been compromised, quick reporting helps minimize damage and protect the university community.

What to Report
- Phishing emails or suspicious messages
- Compromised or stolen credentials
- Lost or stolen university devices
- Malware or ransomware infections
- Unauthorized access to data or systems
- Suspicious account activity
- Social engineering attempts

How to Report Phishing Emails

Method 1: Use the Report Phishing Button
In Outlook, select the suspicious email and click 'Report Phishing' in the toolbar. This forwards the email to the security team for analysis.

Method 2: Forward to Security Team
Forward the suspicious email as an attachment to security@university.edu. Include 'Phishing Report' in the subject line.

Reporting Compromised Accounts

If you believe your account has been compromised:
1. Immediately change your password at passwords.university.edu
2. Review recent account activity for unauthorized access
3. Report the incident at security.university.edu/report or call (555) 123-4599
4. Check connected applications and revoke suspicious access

Reporting Lost or Stolen Devices
University-owned devices: Report immediately to IT Help Desk for remote wipe and tracking.
Personal devices with university data: Report so IT can revoke access tokens and monitor for suspicious activity.

Emergency Response
For active security incidents affecting multiple users or critical systems, call the IT Security Emergency Line: (555) 123-4599 (24/7).

After Reporting
The IT Security team will acknowledge your report within one business day. For phishing reports, you'll receive feedback on whether the email was legitimate. For account compromises, security staff will guide you through remediation steps and monitor for further suspicious activity.

Prevention Tips
- Never share your password or MFA codes
- Verify unexpected requests through official channels
- Keep software and operating systems updated
- Use unique passwords for different services
snippet: How to identify and report phishing attempts, compromised accounts, and other security incidents to the IT Security team.
